society.membership: American Society of Cell Biology (ASCB),Biophysical Society (BPS)
climate.open:
As a postdoc, I don't feel included a lot of times. 
See your definition of "climate", "[...]faculty, staff, and students[..]" I am neither of those things.
If I was a student I would have classes, etc...
If I was a staff I would have a better salary and benefits.
If I was a faculty I would have a more "permanent" position.
There are plenty of opportunities for students (which I am not anymore) developed by my campus and by scientific societies that I can not benefit from. There is not as much support for postdocs; students have their grad school program, etc... and staff/faculty have the institution behind them. Postdocs, at best, have their PI (one single person).

climate.open: Overall, I feel relatively comfortable at my university, in my department, and in my lab. I am in a very interdisciplinary field, but my university is pretty open about embracing different ways of thinking and approaches to research. My colleagues have all been pretty supportive. However, I do find myself constantly struggling with imposter syndrome, and feeling like I don't really belong or deserve to be here, which could relate to my struggles with mental health or just with how the institution of "science" has been presented to me throughout my life.
gender.specific: Cis-gender or I do not identify within the LGBTQ+ community as it relates to my gender identity
college.gen: Master’s degree (for example: MA, MS, MEd, MSW, MBA)
disability.specific: Mental health and/or psychological disability (e.g. bipolar disorder, depression)
society_included_lgbtq_open: It's so tricky to answer this question, because to me, my LGBTQ+ identity is so personal, but I know everyone is different and will have different needs. What I can say is that having representation is so important. I am only out to a few people, and the main reason that is is because of how many positive role models I've seen around me since I've been in graduate school/grown more into myself. I think if societies create a really safe space where people are encouraged to be who they are, it can inspire people who are still struggling with accepting themselves or being more open in the world. Maybe having a mentorship program/groups around identity, having some kinds of forums where people can anonymously ask questions, and even highlighting queer scientists on panels or as speakers, would be helpful. Also, maybe even for folks who feel comfortable, having an optional little rainbow pin or ribbon on at a conference could help (though I know for some people that would be too much). For me, whenever I see someone who is out, it makes me feel more safe and comfortable myself.
workplace_included_lgbtq_open: As a not-super-out LGBTQ+ individual, I think my workplace community seems like it does a pretty good job, but it's hard for me to say if/how that would change if I was more open. I've actually come out to more people partially because of the people I've met in graduate school- it is so empowering to see so many queer people who are unapologetically themselves and are accepted for who they are, and to see people who celebrate it as part of their identity. Before grad school, at educational institutions I was at I didn't have hardly any out queer friends, or spaces where I felt comfortable engaging with my identity in that way, but at my workplace now it's been so different. I think continuing to celebrate the LGBTQ+ identity, and highlight just what great humans these people are, helps a lot.

society.membership: Genetics Society of America (GSA),Society for the Advancement of Biology Education Research (SABER)
subdiscipline: Cell biology,Developmental biology,Discipline-based education (DBER),Genetics,Molecular biology,Molecular genetics
climate.open:
I do not like the climate at my institution as a whole (and more recently, to the turn that the climate at the Faculty level has taken). It goes counter to a lot of my values and beliefs; it is a place that prioritizes profits and "global rankings" over students' education and experiences, and over the way in which many of the employees are treated. It claims it is doing so much good, but pretty much all of it is performative. It claims it is a leader against climate change, and then it takes actions that encourage people to drive to campus instead of using public transport, and it cuts down trees in favour of energy-poor concrete buildings full of completely unaffordable condos. 
However, the units in which I work (department and program) are wonderful, full of great, collegial people, most of whom are doing their best to support students (not only in their education). The leadership in one of my units, in particular, is extremely active in supporting (with actions, not so much words), encouraging, and celebrating all members of the unit, with special attention to the "unsung heroes" and those who are in less of a position of power. 
The physical classrooms where I teach vary in quality and climate. The one where I most often teach has a great layout, is generally very accessible, and even has some associated "breakout rooms" that students who need more quiet during individual or small group activities can use. However, it has no windows or ventilation, and the sound is terrible.
The students with whom I work are, by and large, wonderful. They tend to be very supportive of each other, collaborative, willing to work hard, and willing to advocate for each other.
gender: A gender that is not listed
gender_10_TEXT: "Gender" is not a concept that I grew up with (it did not exist, where/when I was a kid). I don't know what it means to identify as [insert gender here] - I know what it feels to be me, and what it feels like to identify as, let's say, a biologist ("You know you are a biologist if...."). They should have a checklist for genders, then I could answer the question truthfully :)

My current insitution has been welcoming to me. My department has been even more welcoming and I am happy to work in a supportive environment for my postdoc (can't say that for my PhD department though). My lab is incredibly inclusive and supportive and wonderful. 

However, my main concern with the university is how it is predominantly white and wealthy. The student body does not reflect the diversity of the area/state I am in.

climate.open:
While my department is full of good people and I feel a sense of belonging and community there as we are working to be better, I still feel (after 15 years of teaching) that I am an imposter to some degree in the classroom. 

I am not happy with the lip service that our university gives to inclusion (particularly for faculty, which ranges from issues with representation, searches to improve representation, and inequitable compensation practices that put equity-deserving groups at the low end of the payscale), nor some of the assumptions they make about faculty and staff. 

I don't really have a research group, although I "head up" a nascent SoTL group in biology with several teaching focused faculty members (such as myself) and a few research students. I feel like the climate is good there, but need to check in more with the other members (students and faculty).

society.membership: Society for the Advancement of Biology Education Research (SABER)
climate.open: Climate at the campuses I am a part of have a strong culture and climate that focuses more on diversity vs inclusion. Some of the ways this mostly shows up for me in my work. I find it difficult to advocate for myself and engage in particular meetings as a neurodivergent person given general accessibility issues (ex. giving more than one person the chance to talk, ample time for discussion, agendas!). At the department level, I may have allies but in departmental/division meetings, committees, it is clear that people are very resistant to change and often conflate diversity and inclusion (ex. "I don't see what the problem is, we have SO many Hispanic students! How can they not feel welcome here?").
college.gen: Some college but no degree
disability.specific: Learning disability (e.g. dyslexia),Chronic health condition (e.g. cancer, diabetes)
job: A non-tenure track faculty member or research staff
society_included_lgbtq_open:
Discuss, highlight, and address more topics (including research) with an intersectional lens, a focus on intersectionality. I think SABER has been intentional when bringing in speakers for their online series, and I would like to see more outside of that, in other groups, particularly those who do not have an BER focus like SABER. Race in this country is still often seen on a scale of Black or white, "color" and "not of color", or race-neutral, that racial identities are in silos and I see that thinking extending to how my colleagues perceive identities beyond race. 

It will be difficult to get to the deeply needed aspects of inclusionary practice if a majority of the topics we discuss and research we support do not move in a direction that directly acknowledges the positionality of the work we do and how we are including or at the bare minimum, considering intersectionality as a part of our research/research process, teaching, etc. There is still a huge sentiment of biology/science being race-neutral and that is still being taught in how many of my colleagues are also mentoring/teaching their students. I find that also reflective in the research and some discussions that we have. More discussions and research that center intersectionality in all of our work can only benefit us. They do not need to be a part of a special inclusion series, just a normal part of the work.

Not sure where to put this but I want to note that in my previous answers, it was difficult to pick a strong answer as majority of the LGBTQ+ identified professionals at the campuses I work at are white, male-presenting, able bodied, often have pay that is significantly more than others, and have been on the campus for at least 10 years. Many of them do not have a problem with sharing who their partners are, and many would not experience being stigmatized and/or harmed, with jobs at risk as our colleagues who do not identify similarly.
workplace_included_lgbtq_open:
'-Make space. My campus/department can start by changing it's practices and theyre often very simple fixes. Ex. 1) in meetings, where not everyone can just "jump in" during the meeting, but be very intentional about who is in the room, and making sure that there is a way for everyone to provide feedback whether before, during, or after a meeting. 
Ex. 2) Adding pronouns and preferred names to all forms. I have students and colleagues who have been deadnamed and misgendered for 2 years despite changing their names and pronouns on their employee/student record. Who were not able to get paid or financial aid disbursed in a timely manner because they had to use the government name they had on file despite changing it where I would imagine would be the most important place to reflect the changes. 
My workplace can also do better at changing their hiring practices. The questions and scales used for hiring are incredibly odd, and outdated. It's like creating a survey for rating how cute a puppy is but only asking you to multiple select how fast its tail was wagging.
 
They can hire more people who value inclusion in this way and are able to help challenge this fast paced (but slow-churning because the steps aka barriers come up so quickly), traditional academic culture, given the odd nature of us being at a "non-traditional" school - a community college. 
-Taking on an intersectional lens to all that they do and supporting the work of social justice. We need professional development trainings that are current, not just for faculty but for all professionals. We cannot have people who work with students in a low-income community not be familiar with the impacts of social inequities, and how that plays into science and everything else. Include people in active membership for societies like these to stay connected in shifting and developing their practice(s) as educators and leaders.
-Provide a way for people of marginalized identities to share concerns and feedback without risk of repercussions, and have those things be addressed in a timely manner. We have affinity groups, but it often takes months if not years (if at all) for the campus/district to address concerns. 

In my previous answers, it was difficult to pick a strong answer as majority of the LGBTQ+ identified professionals at the campuses I work at are white, male-presenting, able bodied, often have pay that is significantly more than others, and have been on the campus for at least 10 years. Many of them do not have a problem with sharing who their partners are, and many would not experience being stigmatized and/or harmed, with jobs at risk as our colleagues who do not identify similarly.

society.membership: I am not currently associated with any of the above societies
I am not currently associated with any of the above societies
climate.open: My lab and my PI have gone the extra mile to ensure that our lab space is safe and inclusive to all. I feel like the department and the university, as well as professional societies, make a lot of empty promises to improve diversity and inclusion without actually taking any actionable steps to make LGBTQ+ folks feel welcomed and valued. Many LGBTQ+ students would benefit from resources and funding, when in reality we are just faced with more diversity trainings. While these trainings are important, there is more that needs to be done, including equal pay and improved sense of worth and value within the workplace.

society_included_lgbtq_open: LGBTQ+ students need funding and resources to find success in their respective societies. We need funding to attend events and meetings. We need the societies to incentivize participation in society events with travel support and scholarships. I would like to see professional societies host LGBTQ+ specific events during meetings to allow for networking.
workplace_included_lgbtq_open: The workplace needs to offer equal pay and resources to members of the LGBTQ+ community. The workplace needs to be less tolerant of hate-speech and problematic behavior from other members of the workplace. If someone else in your department is posting anti-LGBTQ+ rhetoric on social media, there needs to be repercussions for that behavior. Department heads need to take reports of discrimination seriously and have a plan in place for how to address these concerns.

climate.open: I think a lot of my experience of climate comes from my career stage (Assistant Professor) as I feel established and less "at risk" within my campus climate, compared to when I was a student or postdoc and had more combined insecurities about my personal LGBTQ+ identity as well as my career status as a scientist.

society_included_lgbtq_open: More LGBTQ+ networking at conferences, more highlighting of LGBTQ+ individuals within the society, blogs about personal experiences as members of the queer community.
workplace_included_lgbtq_open:
I would like to see my workplace do more to assess and talk about the experiences of LGBTQ+ staff and especially students at my university. In these difficult political times, our students need mentorship and support, and I would like to see more efforts to support those efforts from the top. Athletics in my university gets a ton of money/resources and cultural support. If we invested even a small fraction of that to support the queer community, it would be an amazing thing.
Culturally, folks at my workplace could ask more intentionally about my life as a queer person - it does not need to be specific or directed, but just intentional engagement about my personal life, open-ended enough that I as a queer person can contribute. As an example: At my career stage, most of my colleagues are straight and married with kids, and this is the focus of a lot of conversations outside of work. I engage and listen to their experiences, but as an unmarried queer person without kids, I struggle to identify with those experiences. This is a prevailing experience in the queer community of not identifying with the major "talking points" that bring people together along common interests (family, relationships, etc.)

society.membership: I am not currently associated with any of the above societies
climate.open: As a member of the LGBTQIA+ community, I make it my mission to facilitate safe and inclusive spaces in every situation where I have the power to do so, and to encourage safety and inclusivity in spaces I am a part of but do not control. In the classroom in which I teach, I have control over the environment and thus feel comfortable while also helping students and TAs feel comfortable. As a graduate student, however, I have limited power when it comes to lab, department, or university spaces. I have been in several leadership positions throughout my time in graduate school (and throughout my academic career) and have done what I can to facilitate inclusive spaces, but at the end of the day I am not the one with the power to genuinely effect change. Even as president of the graduate student government, there are severe limitations on what I can do due to the Catholic nature of my university. Without faculty and administration who are willing to advocate for change, the best we can get is small pockets of safe environments at an overall very exclusive university.

society.membership: Society for the Advancement of Biology Education Research (SABER)
climate.open: Generally my work is very welcoming but I find my identity as an instructor/education researcher is not valued by my community or campus, especially in regards to how my position borders both staff and faculty but is also neither. Further, because I don't do bench science anymore, I don't feel like the biology community considers me to really be a part of it. I consider myself to be more a part of the community but I do feel that to others in the field I am no longer a "scientist". Generally I like the biology community at large (some disciplines better than others) over other scientific communities, but there's still that bias that exists that teaching or researching teaching is "less than" and not as important/you've given up or couldn't hack it as a scientist.

society_included_lgbtq_open: I think continue to represent the community and share ways to  be more inclusive in research in terms of representing gender and sexual minorities in data. The presence of LGBTQ+ groups has been incredibly helpful and supportive in SABER and POD.
workplace_included_lgbtq_open: We recently started having grad/postdoc/faculty mixers every quarter for folks in the Life Sciences LGBTQIA+ community which has really increased my sense of belonging in the last year or two. The last few years I've seen greater representation in the field and on campus so I actually feel like things are improving. It could be better of course, but where' I'm located is a very liberal city in the US and is very pro-gay rights. I believe things would be different if I lived in Florida, for example. There are many states I would actively not consider a job in because of their attitudes towards LGBTQ individuals.

climate.open: My institution does not support or value excellence in research. climate.open: I almost always feel de-valued by my administration. I often feel de-valued by my colleagues in my department. I see lots of efforts made at all levels to fight discrimination based on race, gender, and religion, but disability and neurodivergence are largely ignored. A colleague once suggested that since I “will always be limited and need some accommodation” (my own words being quoted back to me) that I “have some humility.” Though I have seen some efforts made to accommodate me in the workplace, I can’t help but still think about how hurtful this was.

society.membership: I am not currently associated with any of the above societies
climate.open: Being at a college in the South in a liberal urban bubble surrounded by a conservative sea is not always the most comfortable.  The city and college is a decent shield.  However academia is rife with exploitation of people, which is harder on the marginalized.  I am a teaching postdoc, so I get hit with more of that.  The program I teach within is actually very good for climate.  We get great comments from the students that they feel safe and motivated to work even though our classes are still a lot of work.  My one issue is that the program director has a dampening effect on my feeling of belonging.  While he is not bad for a straight white man in his 70s, I can still feel the negative impact of his perception about academic effort, toxic overwork, and outdated gender norms.

climate.open: I have worked in the same lab for 5 years, and during this time I published over a dozen scientific articles, earned several awards and a fellowship. Despite this, I feel like an outsider in my group, department, and university. I have never felt a sense of community here, nor have I felt welcome. I'm pretty sure I'm the only openly queer person in my department. Some department leaders blatantly refuse to even look at me. I have been given vague comments from staff regarding murders toward LGBTQ+ members in their home countries. When I was SA'd, I didn't turn to anyone here for support, because there was none to be found for me. My graduation was delayed for arbitrary reasons, and I feel like people do not take me seriously, despite my substantial accomplishments in my field. Do I feel comfortable here? No. I am, however, exuberant about leaving.
gender.specific: Questioning
college.gen: High school diploma or GED
society_included_lgbtq_open: I think that there need to be some seminars on either the contributions of queer scientists or on LGBT+ issues in general.
workplace_included_lgbtq_open: I think that there need to be some seminars on either the contributions of queer scientists or on LGBT+ issues in general. I also think they desperately need to hire more diverse faculty. It's all white/Asian people here with one black person. Mandatory training on LGBT+ issues should be implemented in addition to all the other necessary trainings (such as Title IX training). I think that the curriculum needs to be diversified as well. For example, if we are talking about AIDS we need to talk about the queer scientists who were trailblazers in that area. Also, holding professors accountable for their actions needs to be a priority. Many queer people experience discrimination, but there are no channels to alleviate these issues.

society.membership: I am not currently associated with any of the above societies
climate.open: I have been personally, directly harassed by faculty for being trans. I have been denied teaching opportunities in my dept for being trans. Whenever I have raised these issues to either the dept or to the campus as a whole, I have been told that I am the problem and that I should apologize to the faculty who harass me to "keep the peace". I have been told by admin in the DEI office that I can't ask for non-othering language regarding trans people on surveys because cis people might be confused by the word cis.

gender.specific: Gender-queer or gender non-binary

society_included_lgbtq_open: As a preface, I disagree with this survey lumping gender and sexuality together - I am met with MUCH more hostility based on being transgender than I am based on being queer - and my suggestion reflects this, given the current political climate in the U.S.: Don't host conferences in places where who I am is criminalized.
workplace_included_lgbtq_open: I just want there to be a system in places that doesn't let faculty repeatedly harass trans students with no consequences. I just genuinely don't feel at all safe interacting with certain faculty and even certain labs, because what started the harassment was me asserting a boundary of not being able to assist with an experiment. I am scared to assert that boundary again, because it will be seen as an excuse to harass me. My mentor is good, but extremely passive. There needs to be some sort of institutional mechanism that actually protects marginalized students.

society.membership: I am not currently associated with any of the above societies
climate.open: As a student I've experienced discrimination and intimidation from professors while non-LGBT students didn't seem to face the same treatment. This ranged from being marked poorly on assignments, not being given proper grades (only to have an external examiner review my paper and raise my grade by 20%), to outright intimidation where I was threated with deregistration in one of my compulsory courses for missing a lecture when I was sick (for which I had a doctor note). In the labs I've experienced harassment mostly in the form of heightened scrutiny from lab staff over everything I do which ranged from forcing me to do assigned lab duties at a more frequent interval than is typically expected of others, double-checking log books for any lab I worked in, and a general refusal to provide reagents or assistance when needed (even when this is routinely done for other postgrads).  I've also experienced quite a bit of homophobic gossip, one of our lab managers actually "warned" male students to stay away from me or to not be overly friendly as "you never know what his type is capable of". This behaviour is normalised and universal, most LGBT postgrads switch labs between their degrees due to poor treatment. Some even completely change institutions.
gender.specific: Cis-gender or I do not identify within the LGBTQ+ community as it relates to my gender identity
college.gen: High school diploma or GED
society_included_lgbtq_open: Start by recognizing that we exist. Too often societies simply act like all members/students are straight and have "no idea" that LGBT people are still facing differential barriers to success.
workplace_included_lgbtq_open: At the very least adopt more inclusive language. Many of the invites to events imply your "plus one" must be of the opposite sex and has necessitated LGBT people having to ask if they can also bring their partner to such events. It may also help if they provide resources specific to LGBT people to facilitate access to resources. Sensitivity training for staff is also critical. Beyond this, better infrastructure for LGBT people to report discrimination when it happens. It really doesn't help when the people you report it to are straight and have a tendency to "gas light" people by saying it "wasn't intentional" or "they didn't mean it that way" or "you are overreacting"... only for there to be zero consequences for the guilty parties.

society_included_lgbtq_open: The Society for the Study of Reproduction (SSR), and the American Urological Association (AUA) both already do a pretty good job of creating Queer friendly spaces at our conferences. I do think having clear guidelines on appropriate behavior that folks have to agree to that include very clear instructions on what the reporting and adjudication mechanism is would be very helpful. We have guidelines, but how to report and how victims are protected is less clear.

climate.open: Both campus and department have positives and negatives related to the cultural climate.  There has been progress toward inclusion, but I feel that leadership positions are generally held by people who have been successful in less inclusive climates and thus, change is slow.  I respect the efforts being made at both levels while recognizing that they are not always sufficient for true inclusion and equity.

society.membership: American Society of Cell Biology (ASCB)
climate.open: I am in a R2 institution. Graduate students in general are becoming more fragile in face of difficulty and responsibility, and too dependent on PI to provide solutions. They are also more focused on the benefits now than thinking about growth long-term. PI needs to do more of parenting job than providing scientific guidance. Undergrads are too pre-med occupied, cynical, and grades-driven. More undergrads are not well prepared in high school, coming to college with inflated high school grades. Students in general do not understand and are not willing to understand the pressure faced by instructors. Student advocacy offices are simply approving any requests by students and pass the pressure to instructors. Administrators tend to demand more work from faculty without even talking about compensation (time or money).

society_included_lgbtq_open: I feel included in the GSA. They have LGBTQ+ meetups at conferences and are planning on similar non-meeting meetups in the future. Employees of GSA make me feel included.
workplace_included_lgbtq_open: I'm at a school that historically all female so we have ended up with many LGBTQ+ students and faculty and the environment is generally supportive. It took a long time for me to come out here because I replaced a gay faculty member and I didn't know why he did not get tenure. A spouse of a former faculty member made derogatory comments about another gay faculty member in front of me before I came out. We are in the south so the local climate is not as supportive. I like that we have optional training in this area and discussions about pronouns, etc. I think our Deans or Department Chairs should consider making this a requirement. We already have required training on sexual harassment and age discrimination. I think training for allies would be good.

society.membership: I am not currently associated with any of the above societies
climate.open: While my lab and PI are amazing, I experience major problems in the department and university because of my disability. Despite already being at a disadvantage because of an energy-limiting chronic illness, my department forces me to spend 10-15% of my research time on getting my access needs met. This includes everything from reminding senior management, that no, they cannot just choose to deny a reasonable adjustment under the Equality Act (2010) for no reason and that access needs aren't personal preferences, or that (like a lot of people who use a wheelchair) I'm not suddenly completely unable to walk because I sometimes use a wheelchair, or that my disability didn't magically disappear when the department axed all hybrid access without consultation when they removed COVID protection polies; working with departmental technical staff to actually get adjustments in place; educating everyone around me about (my) disability; dealing with ableist language and behaviour from departmental and college staff , filing and following up the appropriate complaints (currently 4 formal complaints over 5 years) while often having to guide staff through the complaints process myself because they have never run one before. This is physically and mentally exhausting and detrimental to my health. A large number of staff seem to have never worked with a person as disabled as myself before, and educating them is a big time investment, but it's the ones that don't want to be educated that are the worst. While there seems to be a vague understanding that I am at a systematic disadvantage because of my disability, there is no awareness within the department that it's litterally the road blocks that the department are placing in my way that are disabling me.

society_included_lgbtq_open: I personally feel included as a gay woman but I have seen different opinions and behaviours towards transgender people, so I really think trying to tackle that kind of discrimination is important because I think that's still way behind. I also think people are more accepting towards young out people but I'm not sure that's the case for queer older professors in my field. I recently attended a conference where they had pronoun stickers which seemed to cause outrage and people said it had become too woke - I think that probably had more damage to be honest and so I think its really important to try to change perceptions in small ways because otherwise it polarises people. I think having respected figures who are casually out or confident about their identity in a natural way but not making a huge deal about it is the best way to make LGBTQ+ individuals normalised. The minute you shove things on people it starts causing friction and doesn't help anyone.
workplace_included_lgbtq_open: I work in a behavioural genetics institute and that can be a field where some researchers have really discriminatory opinions.. my institute takes that sort of thing very seriously and is currently not a problem, but I do think it would be worth getting prospective applicants to write a diversity statement or something in their job application to try and vet when someone might be very hateful towards certain groups. I know some people within the wider field have some very strong and discriminatory viewpoints that would dramatically change my workplace environment if any of those people came to work with us...

climate.open: My overall experience is positive and I have not experienced direct discrimination or abuse. However, homophobic and specially transphobic remarks are not uncommon, usually just very subtle ones probably due to inexperience, ignorance or just internalised homophobia/transphobia. These are to be expected in the context of a LGBT-phobic society and all of us may eventually make such comments, but the problem comes when, upon confrontation, people are not willing to recognise their mistakes and try to avoid self-criticism by defending "people are too sensitive nowadays".

workplace_included_lgbtq_open: On the whole, I feel my identity at work is accepted. Most of the things that would make me feel more included do not feel tied necessarily to my LGBTQ+ identity. However, things like flexibility in schedule/working hours and improved communication about work expectations would allow me to more easily make time for therapy and other emotional care practices. These would help me feel more comfortable at work in general. Given that as an LGBTQ+ individual, I also have unique stressors in my life (such as acceptance from family, navigating my romantic relationship with a cis straight man, and processing the broader societal LGBTQ+ trauma of news criminalizing my identity and the identities of others in my community), the well-being this work flexibility would offer me is not entirely disconnected from my LGBTQ+identity.

society_included_lgbtq_open: Survey queer members to find out membership and attainment levels relative to non-queer membership, and ask what we need to be supported and what issues we face is the baseline to discover what needs to be done.
workplace_included_lgbtq_open: My institution has made big strides in the past few years. Individuals within the institution (faculty, staff, students) will always be a mixed bag, with varying levels of acceptance and comfort with queer lives and issues. So long as the institution provides support in the face of when members do not, we’ll be in an ok position. At this point in my life, I don’t care if individuals in my sphere don’t support me (that’s nothing new) so long as the institution protects me. At the moment, my biggest rage point is that our insurance doesn’t cover surrogacy for gay male couples (the definition of infertility is strictly heterosexist - I need to prove I’ve been unable to impregnate a woman for my insurance to cover fertility treatments, even though my husband and I have not a single uterus between us) - I’ve spoken to the Dean and out LGBTQ+ liaison in the provost’s office and they all agree that it’s not a priority for them, which is infuriating because it’s a systemic form of discrimination that makes my having a family fundamentally less important to the university than literally any other kind of family formation.

society_included_lgbtq_open: We could have some LGBTQ+ specific events, as reasonable times and with FREE FOOD. Societies need to put their money where their mouth is. At our last annual meeting for the American Society of Horticultural Science there was a session about DEI, but it took place at 7 in the morning and it wasn't clear whether it included breakfast. If societies are serious about these issues, they need to make sure sessions, workshops, working groups, etc. meet at accessible times and they need to do things like offer free food to actually incentivize people to show up.
workplace_included_lgbtq_open: My department works closely with another department that is MUCH less welcoming of LGBTQ+ individuals than my own. It would be great if there could be more cooperative events with the two departments to try and eke the other department along in terms of acceptance. The fact of the matter is that there are gay graduate students in my department who aren't out, not because of our own department, but because they have committee members who are in the other department and are fearful of their reactions.

society.membership: I am not currently associated with any of the above societies
climate.open: I think that my campus climate is inclusive and promotes diversity. However, they tend to homogenize everyone such that there is no CELEBRATION of diversity. There are few social activities/clubs for identity groups (racial, ethnic, or LGBTQ) so we don't really get to hang out with our own "tribe". For example I just learned the guy in the lab across the hall is gay after working here for 5 years. There's no real sense of community within identity groups. Moreover, the few LGBTQ activities that DO happen at our university are overwhelmingly attended by trans and non-binary folk; gay and lesbian employees and students don't feel like we belong in those spaces.

society.membership: American Society of Cell Biology (ASCB)
climate.open: My individual research group is a very welcoming environment, but I do not feel like a part of the community in my department or university. Part of this is just the anonymous feeling of being a trainee, but also, as a member of the LGBTQ+ community, there are aspects of my life experiences and identity that others cannot relate to. I am bisexual, which is a particularly stigmatized identity. If I come out I fear judgement by my peers and the faculty, but if I don't come out it's hard for people to get to know me or to bring my whole self to work. The university as a whole does not clearly value diversity beyond lip service, and sometimes seems to view it as detrimental to or at odds with academic excellence, despite the research that shows the opposite.
gender.specific: Questioning,Cis-gender or I do not identify within the LGBTQ+ community as it relates to my gender identity
college.gen: Bachelor’s degree (for example: BA, BS)
disability.specific: Chronic health condition (e.g. cancer, diabetes)
society_included_lgbtq_open: 1: Discussion spaces, conference sessions, or even whole meetings are really powerful in my experience. I attended a LGBTQ+ scientists session at ASCB some years ago; it was very impactful for me and I still reflect on it often. (Sadly, the event really highlighted the pain and struggles of LGBTQ+ scientists, especially trainees.) 2: I think it is critical to continue to do these types of surveys, and to collect overall demographic information about LGBTQ+ scientists in these societies. We are so often overlooked in surveys and censuses, and this makes it very difficult to quantify the challenges we face and to design strategies to address them.
workplace_included_lgbtq_open: The thing I would most appreciate is access to identity-specific mentorship- professional guidance from more senior LGBTQ+ researchers about how to navigate life as an out scientist. For example, I want to be out in the workplace to bring all of my best self to work and to support my community, but I am not sure how to navigate this. When I came out in graduate school the response was very mixed and sometimes painful, so now as a postdoc I am not out to everyone in my new workplace. I would also appreciate some acknowledgement of the unique challenges faced by LGBTQ+ scientists, and a seat at the table for us in conversations about diversity. A huge challenge for us is that the NIH does not consider LGBTQ+ identity as part of diversity in life sciences, and so we are often left out of the conversation in biology departments. This makes it even riskier to come out- we expose ourselves to discrimination without recognition for the positive contributions we can make to a diverse workplace.

Language. Don't take straight/cis/etc to be the norm and occasionally use inclusive language. Don't assume. Always be inclusive. Be ok with talking about it without being too eager to "befriend" LGBTQ+ folks (overcompensation).

climate.open: I am in a male-dominated field. Sometimes I am the only woman in a space. Most men in this space lack the capacity to understand how that may feel or how their actions make me feel like I do not belong. This makes me angry because it takes extra energy to make space for myself.

society_included_lgbtq_open: My field is agriculture, which is largely rural and more conservative beliefs abound. This makes any change hard because the society is made up of individuals that have negative opinions against LGBTQ+ and a silent majority who don't realize they have to be proactive. I think more bystander intervention would be helpful.
workplace_included_lgbtq_open: 50 years ago it was illegal to be gay in the federal government (because of communism...see Lavender Scare). The legacy of Don't Ask, Don't tell is still pervasive. A lot of people now don't really care, but it is safer and easier to not be out, so people remain closeted. When you see people's gayness being advertised (e.g. Pride Month announcements), many people wonder why this is relevant to their work but that is because they do not realize the history. It is hard to get people to understand as an institution because the self reflection has to come from the individual.

society_included_lgbtq_open:
Do a better job at recognizing LGBTQ+ as part of DEI efforts.
I feel the biggest way that LGBTQ+ people are affected right now is being basically ignored / left out. We don't benefit from tokenization, but also are harmed from exclusive practices (e.g., excluded from collaborations; not given leadership opportunities). People are conscious of issues like gender and racial balance, but no conception of how LGBTQ+ fits into this.
workplace_included_lgbtq_open:
Hire more queer people! 
But also, do a better job at organizing and bringing together queer people across campus. Hire someone who's job it is to do that, rather than relying on individuals to self-organize.

In recent years I had become more willing to not conceal my gender identity, but current events are making me return to the closet.

society.membership: I am not currently associated with any of the above societies
climate.open:
The University I work at in  Canada uses only my second language and often, people who can speak English prefer to tell you they cannot so that you are forced to communicate in French.
I am extremely uncomfortable around my direct supervisor who advertised a 3 year postdoc position and then could only provide 2-week to 4-month long contracts. My position started 3 months late, leaving me unemployed, and at this time and between every short contract he told me that 'at most, I'd not get paid for 2-4 weeks'. When I complained, he told me that the other postdocs with children don't complain, so I shouldn't either. He has also told me several times that he is sorry I find it so stressful to not have reliable employment. After some time of working in the position, the other postdoc told me that I should have at least 3 months of savings in order to be able to sustain myself while working for this individual. This is the biggest thing, set aside not being able to remember my name, speak to me or about me using my proper pronouns, or failing to speak about me using 'Dr.' while using 'Dr.' to introduce male colleagues.

workplace_included_lgbtq_open: Recognize my pronouns. I also suspect that my advisor tries to only hire women so that he can manipulate them more. On nearly all occasions that I have interacted with my advisor, he says things that I don't think he would ever say to a man. I try not to meet with him one-on-one, and he behaves in those meetings, but not when I have to meet with him alone. Maybe the workplace could require in-person training for the faculty so that they are faced directly with how their behavior is wrong sometimes and give them options for better behaviors that they could try out.

society_included_lgbtq_open: Be active voices regarding inclusion, diversity and equality, but also the kind of behaviours that are expected of their members and the ones that are discouraged
workplace_included_lgbtq_open: Kew has actively been trying to make it more inclusive and diverse. However, Science is extremely conservative and still retains a very dated and prejudice-heavy culture of exclusion, bullying and harassment. There need to be more direct and intense actions within Science to address this culture, including empowering queer employees, educating its staff, and punishing any kind of queerphobic behaviour. In the end, this culture will only change once the people fostering are no longer in the institution. While institutions still believe it's OK to have a racist, sexist, queerphobic, xenophobic, etc. employee because they are productive or are renowned in the scientific community, they will continue to voice to their staff that their wellbeing, health and safety are not a priority when compared to fame and status.

climate.open: The climate is obsessed with DEI, neo-Marxism, postmodernism and has abandoned any and all commitment to meritocracy and Enlightenment rationalism. This obsessions with inclusivity only promotes division and aids tokenism and mediocrity. We should be concerned with competency, efficiency, openness and objectivity. It is not only embarrassing that we have been taken off course and bullied by a hyper-vocal minority, but also very sad. Is contemporary science really the employment of scientific methodologies? Karl Popper would be very disappointed as am I. Prefer that we were as obsessed with finding solutions to humanities legitimate problems.

society.membership: International Society for Stem Cell Research (ISSCR)
climate.open:
In my last experience as Ph.D. student I was member of an international consortium consisted by members from different faculties in different countries. I felt very comfortable in the consortium with a strong sense of belonging. We meet each other periodically for several formal and informal activities.
The campus was inspiring because there were always students everywhere. The environment was super clean, accessible, but sometimes, the climate (air conditioning/heater) was not appropriately adjusted. There were several foragers as me and events for socializing. I never participated of none of them. 
The department performed annually a conference and it was helpful for knowing other students and socializing. 
Our lab was quite isolated, therefore using the facilities of the department always required to move for another building. Our team was always engaged in contributing for the advance of the projects and provides the necessary support.
Be in a classroom aways represented a strong sense of belonging for me. The university is my house and I feel very comfortable in both situations, as instructor and student. In my Ph.D. I held few presentations for several publics, mentored a student, and watched inspired classes from the faculty and other collaborators.

climate.open:
My situation is unique in that I have transferred PhD programs because of anti-LGBTQ harassment and violence in the city of the first university, although the department there was not much better. I wish this had been clearer at recruitment, but everyone claimed this Ecology and Evolution department was tolerant and progressive. In this first program, queer students were not welcome nor respected. While I was the second non-binary / trans student in that department, that first non-binary student was kicked out of the program during my first year there; the student was not blameless, but the faculty, staff, and students talked about them with vitriol, blame, disgust, and disbelief. I was taken aback and shocked to hear the sentiments. It was repulsive how often they were misgendered and spoken ill of. Eventually, when I opened up about the harassment and violence I experienced in the town, I faced similar criticism, disbelief, and disgust. I was told I was lying and exaggerating about my experiences, that I could not be experiencing what I said given how liberal the city was. I never felt so gaslit in my life. The "Good Ole Boys" nature of the department meant that anytime an effeminate person spoke up, they would be seriously interrogated and unlikely to be believed. I questioned whether I belonged in science and whether I even wanted to associate myself with people of these opinions. I sank into a deep depression, because I could not explore the town safely (in 1.5 years, 24 instances of harassment and violence, streets and grocery stores were the worst) and I felt ostracized on campus. I knew I had to leave regardless.

I transferred to a better program and moved across the country after my second year. Faculty at the first program, particularly my first advisor, took it poorly. Faculty told me not to share publicly about the harassment and violence I experienced; I shared experiences about the town anyway (not the department or school), in hopes that other non-binary and trans students would avoid the area. I was called into meetings and screamed at for ruining the reputation of the city, the university, and the department. Eventually I was apologized to and told that I did nothing wrong, but I was nearly fired for sharing my experiences. 

Thankfully, the department I transferred to is so much better. In this survey I respond for my current and second department. My department has other queer students and they are well respected; it was one of the reasons I chose to join the program. While some faculty have struggled with pronouns in class and some questionable statements about gender and race have been made (one faculty member has made comments that are alarmingly similar to Fox News talking points), the department as a whole has been fabulous, respectful, and welcoming. Faculty, staff, and students have treated me with dignity and respect, and they listened to what I went through at the previous school with only acceptance and sympathy. Not a single soul has spoke ill of me to my knowledge, and people frequently offer their condolences for such an awful experience at the last school. I have not been harassed at all in the 8 months that I have lived here. It is incredible.

society_included_lgbtq_open: Professional societies can stop promoting facile frameworks of "sex as a biological variable" - sex is as much a social variable as is gender, and to treat it as a simple binary based on morphology rather than a set of highly socially categorized interacting traits with strongly overlapping distributions contributes to the marginalization of everyone who falls outside of group means, especially trans and intersex people. The great wins of the feminist movement were to de-emphasize sex as deterministic. "Sex" is not a mechanistic variable, and to treat it as such is, simply, bad science and actively rolls back social progress.

climate.open: My faculty position is in Texas.  Individuals are usually (but not always) fine, but administration and local laws are not.
gender.specific: Cis-gender or I do not identify within the LGBTQ+ community as it relates to my gender identity
college.gen: Higher than a Master’s degree (for example: PhD, MD, JD)
society_included_lgbtq_open: Inclusive award nomination processes.  I can not apply for LGBTQ specific awards because that will put a target on my head. To get tenure at an R1, I need to demonstrate the that my work has an impact and awards are one potential mechanism but I don't have a strong advocate at my university who will do so.  What does the award nomination and selection process look like?  Can you self nominate?  Is the selection process sensitive to differential resources or challenges?
workplace_included_lgbtq_open: My institute is often "just following the law" but the laws are exclusionary. They could believe and support me, rather than "the system", when complaints that are based in homophobia come my way.  In my time, my spending on lab purchases and conference travel have been subjected to a higher level of scrutiny and the level of support for ordering and finance tracking has been lower than that of the other PIs in the department.  This fluctuates and is directly correlated with the arrival and departure of homophobic members of the admin team.

society.membership: American Society of Cell Biology (ASCB)
climate.open: My school is albert einstein college of medicine so there is priority to the medical students in terms of support. I feel like the administration does not vouch for the well being of graduate students. There  have been multiple cases of student maltreatment and the admin does not address them properly. The PI I am working with right now has a track record of maltreatment towards students. I have faced incidents when this occurs to me and when I voiced my concerns admin suggested that I stay in the lab and try to graduate sooner rather than later. These experiences have made me want to move away from academia and find a healthier workplace in another sector. On the other hand, there are some professors who are very supportive and understanding and have helped me continue my path in graduate school. I am very grateful for their presence in this community. Other students have also supported me during my time here and they make this place feel like home.

climate.open: I am at a European institution which was run by a rather fascist dictatorial guy; there are also definite ageist and misogynistic tendencies in the culture.  The president told me I was not good enough, would never get tenure, was too old to get another job and should quit science, offered me a job as a graduate writing coach.  And then made sure I didn't get tenure. I am about to move to a tenured position at UCLA where I hope I will feel much more welcomed.

climate.open: I believe I'm the only openly queer person at my agency (and one of the few POC). My lab is very progressive and accepting but almost everyone outside of my department/lab, including upper management, are extremely cold and at best, don't even consider members of the LGBTQIA+ community when making decisions, speaking about agency policies and issues, or even in talking about the communities we serve as a public agency. At worst, some seem very hostile to us.

climate.open: The problems that make me feel uncomfortable have all improved incrementally since the pandemic and the murder of George Floyd.  However, the problems at my R1 university (elitism ... less a lack of respect for individual needs but a lack of will to accommodate them in a face-saving manner -- blindness to the many ways each of us has been brainwashed as children and teens, so that individuals let alone institutions cannot see false assumptions) are so entrenched, in our faculty and staff, in our students -- that I am guessing I will never feel more than neutral or occasionally comfortable in this particular climate for the remainder of my working life.

climate.open: I was pleasantly surprised my large corporation (or perhaps, at the very least among my entire office of ~300 employees) implemented pronouns in email signatures, and the overwhelming majority of my colleagues added their pronouns. I live and work in a very LGBTQIA+ welcoming and supportive city / geographical area however, so it wasn’t wholly unexpected. One notable effect was noticing most pointedly how I was the only person in my office using alternative pronouns - underlining how I was in a distinct minority. Because of the pandemic I am uncertain if my coworkers refer to me as my stated pronouns when I am not present. That being said I do not feel I have any less respect than anyone else professionally.

workplace_included_lgbtq_open: My university could run mandatory workshops on topics including sexuality and gender identity for undergraduates--I was required to attend such workshops as an undergrad, and I think they had a positive impact. The university and the department could make stronger statements in support of the LGBT+ community, particularly in the wake of the terrible anti-LGBT+ legislation that has been pushed in my state. At present, LGBT+ news, community events, and statements of support are only put out by individual queer community members and are not promoted by the institution.
